definition: to seize/to take away forcibly/to wrest control of/to compete or strive for/to force one's way through/to leave out/to lose

sentences.english: Many in the opposition viewed it as an attempted power grab by the military.
sentences.chinese: 反對黨陣營中的很多人都將之視爲軍方企圖奪權。

sentences.english: If you breach those responsibilities, you also forfeit your rights.
sentences.chinese: 如果你違背了義務，那也就會被剝奪權利。

sentences.english: Human beings have an inalienable right to invent themselves.
sentences.chinese: 人類有創造他們自己的不可剝奪權利。

sentences.english: There are many people who intrigue against each other for power and position.
sentences.chinese: 很多人因爲奪權謀位而勾心鬥角。

sentences.english: Society as a whole also connives in the denial.
sentences.chinese: 社會上普遍存在縱容剝奪權利的現象。

sentences.english: Earlier the Ukrainian President dissolved Parliament because it claimed it was usurping power.
sentences.chinese: 之前烏克蘭總統解散國會因爲國會聲稱要奪權。

sentences.english: General Sondhi had taken over power from the prime minister.
sentences.chinese: 頌提司令已從總理身上奪權。

definition: outward devotion but inner opposition (idiom); to pay lip service/to agree overtly, but oppose in secret
to fight openly and maneuver covertly (idiom)
running of armed forces/military management/to govern armed forces/to direct troops
lit. to fall behind Sun Shan 孫山|孙山[Sun1 Shan1] (who came last in the imperial examination) (idiom)/fig. to fail an exam/to fall behind (in a competition)
principle of people's livelihood, the third of Dr Sun Yat-sen's 孫中山|孙中山 Three Principles of the People 三民主義|三民主义 (at the time, meaning redistribution of wealth, self-sufficiency and internal trade)
to forfeit sovereignty and humiliate the country (idiom)/to surrender territory under humiliating terms
scramble for power and profit (idiom); power struggle
lit. chasing the wind and clutching at shadows (idiom); fig. groundless accusations/to act on hearsay evidence
